newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-ENGLISH F.A. ASK WRIGHT TO EXPLAIN "PERVERT" REMARK.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-ENGLISH F.A. ASK WRIGHT TO EXPLAIN "PERVERT" REMARK.

text.p: The English Football Association said on Friday it would be asking Arsenal striker Ian Wright for his comments after an extraordinary attack on Sheffield Wednesday manager David Pleat.

Wright reportedly branded Pleat "a pervert" after Pleat protested to the F.A. for two alleged incidents involving the Arsenal forward in the recent Premier league game at Highbury which the Gunners won 4-1.
F.A. spokesman Steve Double said: "We are writing to Ian Wright asking for his observations on the reported comments in today's papers."
The F.A. are believed to be keen to defuse the war of words between the two and Pleat said: "Ian has been misled. His words aren't worthy of comment."
It now seems likely that the Wednesday manager will leave the matter in the hands of the F.A., rather than taking legal action.
Pleat called for an inquiry after Wright was caught on television pulling the dreadlocks of Wednesday's Dutchman, Regi Blinker, and stamping on Yugoslav defender Dejan Stefanovic.
Wright denies the accusations and is quoted in today's Daily Mail as saying: "He (David Pleat) can do what he likes. He can report me to the FA, but I just ask why is he doing it.
"But if I do have to appear at the FA, I'll have my say about David Pleat. He's a pervert -- and you can print that."
Wright was referring to newspaper revelations nine years ago that Pleat was cautioned by police three times for kerb-crawling. The publicity forced him to resign as Tottenham manager.
Wright was also reported to have said: "He couldn't have had much petrol in his car because he was always driving around so slowly."
Pleat moved on to manage at Leicester, Luton and now Wednesday, who led the Premiership after the first few games this season. The 50-year-old has not been involved in any further scandal.

Wright, speaking after Arsenal's UEFA Cup exit at the hands of Borussia Moenchengladbach, has accused Wednesday of sour grapes after losing the game. "For him to say I pulled Regi Blinker's hair out of malice is nonsense. It was just a joke. I have spoken to Regi since and he knows that. He hasn't a problem," he said.
"There is no way I deliberately stamped on Stefanovic. I might have caught him as I came down after jumping for the ball, but that's all. There was nothing at the time to suggest otherwise.
"It just seems sour grapes by Sheffield Wednesday. We beat them 4-1, they had Des Walker sent off and now they're making all this fuss and accusing me."
Wright has frequently been in trouble with the English F.A. and been fined and suspended for various offences over the last five years.
